MACRO_UNIT_NAME.description: The macro unit name provides the standardized label assigned to a mapped geologic unit, representing a regionally recognized grouping of rock with shared stratigraphic context.

MACRO_STRAT_NAME.description: The stratigraphic name identifies the formal stratigraphic unit (such as formation, member, or group) to which the mapped rocks belong, reflecting their position within the geologic column.

MACRO_LITHOLOGY.description: The lithology describes the dominant rock material or materials present in the unit, capturing composition and texture that directly influence mechanical and hydraulic behavior.

MACRO_AGE_MIN.description: The minimum geologic age represents the youngest possible time of formation for the unit, expressed in millions of years, constraining when deposition or emplacement ended.

sentences: Recent geologic formations under 2.6 million years are typically associated with modern sedimentary processes and have minimal lithification.
Quaternary formations between 2.6 and 23.03 million years are characterized by glacial and interglacial cycles, influencing sediment deposition and erosion patterns.
Tertiary formations between 23.03 and 66 million years reflect significant tectonic activity and the development of modern continental configurations.
Mesozoic formations between 66 and 252.17 million years are marked by the breakup of supercontinents and the dominance of dinosaurs, with significant sedimentary and volcanic activity.
Paleozoic formations between 252.17 and 541 million years encompass the rise of complex life and major orogenic events, resulting in diverse rock types and structures.
Precambrian formations exceeding 541 million years represent the Earth's earliest crustal development, often highly metamorphosed and structurally complex.

MACRO_AGE_MAX.description: The maximum geologic age represents the oldest possible time of formation for the unit, expressed in millions of years, constraining when deposition or emplacement began.

sentences: Very recent geologic formations under 50 million years are typically associated with active tectonic regions and may influence seismic design considerations.
Recent formations between 50-200 million years often represent stable geologic conditions with moderate seismic activity potential.
Intermediate formations between 200-1000 million years are generally stable and provide a reliable foundation for bridge infrastructure with low seismic risk.
Ancient formations between 1000-2500 million years are characterized by high stability and minimal seismic activity, ideal for long-term infrastructure planning.
Prehistoric formations exceeding 2500 million years represent some of the oldest and most stable geologic conditions, with negligible seismic concerns but potential for unique engineering challenges.

MACRO_DESCRIPTION.description: The descriptive text summarizes the geologic characteristics of the unit, including depositional environment, material variability, structure, and notable features relevant to engineering and geotechnical interpretation.
